conclusion: To find when the object's velocity is at its maximum, analyze the acceleration-time graph.
The y-axis represents acceleration in m/s² and the x-axis represents time in seconds.
The area under the curve in an acceleration-time graph represents the change in velocity.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the acceleration is constant at 2 m/s².
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 m/s².
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the acceleration decreases linearly from 0 m/s² to -2 m/s².
From t = 3 to t = 4 seconds, the acceleration is constant at -2 m/s².
Calculate change in velocity from t = 0 to t = 1 second: Area = 1 x 2 = 2 m/s.
Calculate change in velocity from t = 1 to t = 2 seconds: Area = 0.5 x 1 x 2 = 1 m/s.
Calculate change in velocity from t = 2 to t = 3 seconds: Area = 0.5 x 1 x 2 = -1 m/s.
Calculate change in velocity from t = 3 to t = 4 seconds: Area = 1 x (-2) = -2 m/s.
Total change in velocity from t = 0 to t = 2 seconds is 2 + 1 = 3 m/s.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, velocity decreases by 1 m/s.
From t = 3 to t = 4 seconds, velocity decreases by 2 m/s.
The velocity is at its maximum at t = 2 seconds, after which it starts to decrease.
